title: 115_hr876
content: The Act may be cited as the "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017". It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. The Act defines key terms such as Administration, Administrator, air carrier, appropriate congressional committees, foreign air carrier, intelligence community, and secured area. The Act defines key terms related to airport security, including "secured area," "Security Identification Display Area," and "sterile area" as per section 1540.5 of title 49, Code of Federal Regulations. SEC. 3. COST AND FEASIBILITY STUDY. The Administrator must conduct a cost and feasibility study on implementing security measures at airports, including secure doors, surveillance video recording, and advanced screening technologies. The study required under subsection (a) will include information on employee screening costs at airports that screen 100% of employees accessing secured areas. It will assess costs of establishing entry and exit points and compare costs and effectiveness of security features with the Federal Government and airports. The Comptroller General will review the study for quality and reliability within 60 days of receiving it. The Comptroller General of the United States will report to relevant committees on the results of the review required under subsection (a) of the study. SEC. 4. AIRPORT WORKER EDUCATION AND SECURITY AWARENESS. The Administrator will collaborate with various stakeholders to enhance security awareness among airport workers regarding insider threats and access controls. They will also assess credentialing standards to address insider threats to aviation security. The Administrator will require airport operators to submit social security numbers for individuals applying for access to the Security Identification Display Area to enhance security vetting. Applicants who do not provide their social security number may be denied access. Additionally, airport operators must include a notice in applications informing applicants that credential holders may be screened at any time while accessing the area. Applicants who do not provide their social security number may be denied access. Additionally, airport operators must include a notice in applications informing applicants that credential holders may be screened at any time while accessing the area. SEC. 5. SECURING AIRPORT WORKER ACCESS. The Administrator will work with airport operators and the Aviation Security Advisory Committee to identify advanced technologies, including biometric identification, for securing employee access to airport areas. Additionally, all credentialed aviation workers will undergo continuous vetting through the FBI's Rap Back Service to detect insider threats. Insider threat education and mitigation measures will be implemented, and playbook operations will be ensured by the Administrator. The Administrator will conduct covert testing of employee inspection operations at airports to measure security effectiveness and provide results to airport operators, air carriers, and foreign air carriers. Annual reporting on these operations will be required. The Administrator will establish a national database of individuals with revoked airport badges and set up reporting mechanisms for airlines and airport operators to submit data and access the database. Establish a process for individuals to correct mistaken entries in the database and have their names removed. The Department of Homeland Security leads insider threat coordination efforts at airports, working with other government entities, air carriers, and airport operators. The Administrator must submit a plan for recurring IT security reviews within 90 days. No additional funds are authorized for these requirements. The Clerk, Karen L. Haas, attests to the information provided.
